bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Alberto Recio, April 30, 1940

div1.p: Hench seeks information on a photograph taken at the presumed site of Camp Lazear or Camp Columbia.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Alberto Recio, April 30, 1940
div1.opener:
April 30, 1940
Dr. Alberto Recio
Carlos III 1117
Habana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Recio:
div1.p:
I had the pleasure of meeting you recently with Dr. Ramos, Secretary
for Defense, at the time I was trying to identify the location of Camp Lazear.
Dr. Ramos was kind enough to give me a copy of the old photograph of the Framboyant
tree and the little house on the opposite side of Camp LazearColumbia.

I would appreciate it very much indeed, if you would drop me a line,
telling me your own connection with this photograph, from whom you received it,
what it was supposed to represent and how it was identified presumably as Camp
Lazear. I understood you to say that you thought Dr. Agramonte had himself told
Dr. Alvare that he did not recognize the house but thought he recognized the
tree. I suspect that if Dr. Agramonte did recognize this tree, he must have
meant that it was the site of Camp Columbia tent hospital for the yellow fever
experiments, and not Camp Lazear. However, I shall be grateful for whatever
information you can give me, as I have been asked to give a formal report, not
only to Dr. Ramos and the Cuban government, but also the Curator of the United
States Army Medical Museum and to the President of Washington and Jefferson
College.
Would you kindly give me Dr. Alvare's name and address?
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
